snippet: The decision by Superintendent Eddie Johnson comes nearly two years after Officer Jason Van Dyke fired 16 shots at the 17-year-old African-American....
abstract: Chicago Police Superintendent Eddie Johnson calls for firing of seven officers accused of making false statements about fatal shooting of Laquan McDonald by Officer Jason Van Dyke in 2014; dashboard camera video contradicted officers' claims, pointing to 'code of silence' and willingness to lie among officers.

byline.original: By MITCH SMITH and RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr
byline.contributor: Mitch Smith reported from Chicago, and Richard A. Oppel Jr. from New York.

lead_paragraph: The decision by Superintendent Eddie Johnson comes nearly two years after Officer Jason Van Dyke fired 16 shots at the 17-year-old African-American.

headline.main: 7 Chicago Officers Face Firing Over Laquan McDonald Cover-Up
headline.print_headline: Chicago Officers Face Firing in Police Shooting Cover-Up
